page.title: 02PINGLE WOOD CUTTING, WARBOYS
page.content: {Pingle Wood Cutting}used to be part of the railway branch line that ran from Somersham to Ramsey. Passenger trains stopped running on the line on 22nd. September, 1930 and even freight services were stopped in 1964. It is now a nature reserve run by the Bedfordshire and Huntingdon Naturalists Trust. Because it was a railway cut into the side of a hill you go up and down slopes and ramps and steps and into a tunnel. Many species of wild flowers and grasses can be seen there. In the spring there are violets and bluebells. In summer there are dog roses, ox-eye daisies, pink and white clovers and lords and ladies. There are rarer flowers too, such as Ramsons and several types of orchid, like the Early Purple and the Common Spotted.
